Award.AwardTitle: Health Insurance Competition and Healthcare Costs

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Social, Behav & Economic Scie

Division.LongName: Divn Of Social and Economic Sciences

Award.AbstractNarration:
Regulated markets for health insurance are increasingly important in the United States. The goal of this project is to investigate how efficiently these markets can operate, and how well competition between private insurers can work. We focus on the U.S. Medicare program. Almost a third of Medicare beneficiaries now enroll in private insurance plans through Medicare Advantage, and there is detailed administrative data available from Medicare, and recently from private insurers. The fact Medicare private plans operate in parallel to, and in competition with public fee-for-service Medicare, allows for a comparison between private and publicly administered health insurance. The large size of the Medicare program --- the federal government spends over $130 billion annually on Medicare private plans --- also makes it consequential.

The project will address three specific questions: (1) How efficient is the current Medicare managed competition system? (2) Are there program changes that would reduce taxpayer costs without making beneficiaries worse off? (3) Do private plans achieve cost savings relative to public insurance, and if so, how do they do it? To answer these questions, the PIs will use medical claims data to compare the services provided and costs associated with private and public insurance plans. They will also estimate models of health plan choice and competition between insurers, and use these models to analyze the welfare effects of private plans for enrollees, insurers and taxpayers. Findings on the operational and cost differences between private insurance plans and public insurance, and on how well market competition is functioning, will be of interest both to economists and a wider audience.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The project is a study of managed competition in the US Medicare program, which seeked to answer the following questions:(1) How efficient is the current Medicare managed competition system? (2) Are there program changes that would reduce taxpayer costs without making beneficiaries worse off? (3) Do private plans achieve cost savings relative to public insurance, and if so, how do they do it?

We have been pursuing answers to the above questions using a combination of Medicare administrative data on medical claims, beneficiary enrollments, and plan bids, and also private insurer data compiled by the Health Care Cost Institute. We have obtained a number of findings to date. We have used data on beneficiary enrollment decisions and plan bids to estimate a model of imperfect competition between private insurance plans. We have used the model to estimate the benefits (consumer surplus) that accrues to plan enrollees, and how this can be divided into the financial benefits from private plan enrollment and the disutility from restricted choice of providers. We also have used the model to estimate plan markups and the extent of market power, and to run simulations of the effects of various policy changes.

We have used the combination of Medicare and private plan insurance claims to compare healthcare spending and utilization of healthcare services for public and private Medicare enrollees. We have found large spending differences between these populations, around 25% once we match individuals based on location, demographics, and reported health conditions (about half of this, if we also adjust for mortality differences). We have found that these differences are largely attributed to differences in service utilization, and that the prices paid to providers by private insurers and public Medicare are roughly similar.

Circling back to the three questions above, which we seeked to address, we have made progress on each of them as detailed below:

(1) Using our estimates of plan demand and costs, we provide quantitative estimates of the efficiency or private Medicare broken down into the cost savings from reduced healthcare spending in private plans, to be weighed against the loss to enrollees from having restricted choice among providers. We also obtain estimates of how the gains are shared between the plans, the enrollees and taxpayers.

(2) We have used simulations to estimate the effects of changes in the CMS benchmarks that are used to subsidize private plan enrollments. We also have used simulations to estimate the effect of changes in the Medicare "rebate" policythat determines how cost savings by private plans are split between taxpayers andenrollees. We estimate that there is substantial economic value created by having privateplans. The estimates suggest that plans seem to reduce healthcare spending for individual enrollees, and that the cost to enrollees from restricted provider choice issmaller than the financial savings from reduced service utilization. These estimates are of course subject to a number of caveats namely that the quality of care does not deteriorate in private Medicare, and that we adequately are able to control for differences between the public and private Medicare populations. We find that reducing benchmark payments is effective at limiting program costs. Our simulations suggest the reducing these payments will lower plan enrollment by a substantial amount however. Recent evidence suggests this may be an inaccurate prediction so we are working to understand it better.

(3) We have used the private and public claims data to directly address the question of whether privaet plans achieve cost savings. Our study is the first to do this systematically with a large volume of data. Our findings on comparative costs are discussed above, namely that spending is substantially lower in private plans, mainly due to utilization differences. We don't see any indication for quality differences, although half of the difference could be attributed to private plans enrolling healthier population of enrollees.

Taken together, we think that our work provides evidence that offer optimism regarding the cost-saving benefits that could be associated with private Medicare. At the same time, it also highlights the fact that current regulation makes insurers, rather than taxpayers, the main beneficiaries of these cost-savings, and points to possible regulatory changes that could shift more of these benefits toward consumers and taxpayers.
